headline: CNN News Central
subHeadline: AG Garland Testifies Before GOP-Led House Judiciary Committee. Aired 10:30-11a ET

utterances.speaker: MERRICK GARLAND, ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.sentences: I'm not aware, but that's not true. There's nothing cumbersome about the process. All I need to --REP. MIKE JOHNSON (R-LA):  So, those whistleblowers were lying to us under oath? Those whistleblowers are lying?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: I didn't say that. Their description of the process cumbersome is an opinion. It's not a fact question. All I have to do is sign --

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: OK. All right.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: -- a section --

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: Let me get to the fact. Mr. Weiss has been the lead prosecutor on the Hunter Biden case since 2018, correct?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry?

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: Mr. Weiss has been the lead prosecutor on the Hunter Biden case since 2018. Now, here's the question --

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Been the lead prosecutor since he was assigned -- appointed by President Trump --

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: OK. Why?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: -- in a signed --

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: Let me ask you, why has the Justice Department dragged this investigation out for so long? Does it really take years to determine if Hunter Biden lied on a federal forum related to purchasing a firearm?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Mr. Weiss was a longtime career prosecutor. President Trump appointed him as --

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: You're not answering the question. Is that standard procedure? Should it take that long to make such a simple determination?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: I'm answering the question. Give me the opportunity to do so. JOHNSON

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: He was charged with that investigation under the previous administration. He's continued. He knows how to conduct the investigations and I have not intruded or attempted to evaluate that because that was the promise I made to the Senate.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: The whistleblowers gave us testimony about serious misconduct of the Justice Department in regards to the preferential treatment afforded Hunter Biden. Has your office requested an investigation into that?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: There are well-known processes for how whistleblowers make their claims. I am a strong proponent of whistleblowers and a strong defender. We have an inspector general's office. We have an office of professional responsibility. That is the way in which complaints from whistleblowers should be and are appropriately handled.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: I'm out time. I yield back.REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH), CHAIRMAN, JUDICIARY COMMITTEE:  The Chairman yields back. The chair recognizes the ranking member, Mr. Nadler. REP. JERRY NADLER (D-NY), RANKING MEMBER, JUDICIARY COMMITTEE: Thank you. Mr. Attorney General, thank you for being here today. It's no secret that some of my colleagues across the aisle have threatened to shut down the government unless and until the FBI and the Department of Justice are defunded. When Trump lied -- presidential candidate has said we should abolish the FBI altogether. Mr. Attorney General, what would be the impact on America of defunding the FBI?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Defunding the FBI would leave the United States naked to the maligned influence of the Chinese Communist Party, to the attacks by Iranians on American citizens, and attempts to assassinate former officials to the Russian aggression, to North Korean cyberattacks, to violent crime in the United States which the FBI helps to fight against, to all kind of espionage, to domestic violent extremists who have attacked our churches, our synagogues, our mosques and who have killed individuals out of racial hatred. I just -- I cannot imagine the consequences of defunding the FBI, but they would be catastrophic.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: Thank you. I want to turn to Mr. Weiss' investigation and the authority he's been granted to conduct an investigation without interference in whatever way he deems necessary. You testified to the Senate Judiciary Committee on March 1st of this year that David Weiss had, "Full authority over any investigation concerning Hunter Biden." Is that a true statement at the time?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Yes, Mr. Weiss has full authority to conduct his investigation however he wishes. And Mr. Weiss has confirmed that in letters to this committee.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: Thank you. This authority included in ensuring that Weiss would be able to bring charges and jurisdictions outside of Delaware, if necessary, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Mister -- I assured that Mr. Weiss publicly that he would have the authority to bring a case outside of Delaware if he thought that was appropriate.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: Does that remain true today?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Yes, that is true today.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: Has it ever been the case over course of this investigation that Mr. Weiss would not have been able to bring charges outside of Delaware if warranted?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: It's a matter of my authority. I promised he would be able to do that. I think it is apparent in the letters exchanged with the committee and in my last previous testimony in order for a United States attorney or a special counsel or anyone else to bring a case outside his jurisdiction. He requires me to sign a paper called Section 515, that's a statute which permits bringing cases outside of the jurisdiction. I promised that I would do whatever was required to enable Mr. Weiss to bring a case outside his jurisdiction if that's what he thought was appropriate.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: And I assume it was your understanding that Mr. Weiss was fully aware that he could bring charges outside of Delaware, if necessary, when you testified on March 1st?

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Did he ever say or do anything that might make him unsure of where he could bring charges?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Mr. Weiss' own letters reflect that he had never asked me to be a special counsel and that he understood the process for asking for a signature on a Section 515 form.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: There have been accusations that the handling of the Hunter Biden matter is an example of two-tiered system of justice. What's your response to that allegation?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: The Justice Department treats everyone alike regardless of party, regardless of ethnicity, regardless of wealth. Everyone is treated alike. I understand that people may not understand why particular investigations are conducted in particular ways until all of the fact comes, out and that's what we have a court for and all of the explanations will come out with respect to Mr. Weiss, for example, at the end of his period as special counsel. Where the requirement is that he file a public -- a report which I have promised to make public to the extent that's lawful and consistent with the Department of Policy. He will explain his decision to prosecute and not to prosecute.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: Thank you. What are the impacts of members of Congress making such accusations against the DOJ, through baseless accusations from government officials making it more difficult for investigators to do their job and effectively investigate the subject?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Members of the Justice Department are strong and tough, and able -- understand that their job is to do the right thing regardless of any pressures from any order. What is dangerous -- and I'm not talking about the committee, but what is dangerous is when anyone singles out a career prosecutor or a career FBI agent. And we know as a matter of fact that that kind of singling out has led to threats. This is a concern across the board. It is not a concern about anyone in particular.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: I think you would have been justified in referring to the committee. My time has expired. I yield back.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The Chairman yields back. The chair recognizes the gentleman from North Carolina.REP. DAN BISHOP (R-NC):  Mr. Attorney General, you're the only person who could ensure that Mr. Weiss had all of the necessary authority, aren't you?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: I'm the only person who can sign an agreement with respect to special counsel. The authority to do Section 515 can be signed by other people in the department.

utterances.speaker: BISHOP
utterances.sentences: You were aware, ultimately, though, the authority is yours.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BISHOP
utterances.sentences: You made the point that you don't take orders from the president about such things. You decide, ultimately, what the Justice Department will do.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: I announced at the beginning, I promised that he would be able to bring whatever cases he wants, and I have followed through on that promise. I'm permitted to make that kind of promise, and I have made it.

utterances.speaker: BISHOP
utterances.sentences: Did you undertake to inform yourself to interact with him sufficient to ensure that he knew he possessed that authority or that you would see to it that he had all necessary authority.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: I don't think there is any doubt that he knew. He has written three letters to this committee indicating that he understood he had that authority.

utterances.speaker: BISHOP
utterances.sentences: You are also aware though, aren't you, sir, that an -- a senior IRS investigator, whistleblower came forward and testified publicly that Mr. Weiss stated that he did not have such authority. He was not the decider. Are you aware of that?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: I'm aware of the testimony. I was not present at any point during that statement. And Mr. Weiss --

utterances.speaker: BISHOP
utterances.sentences: Have you -- GARLANDhad the authority and he knew that he had it.

utterances.speaker: BISHOP
utterances.sentences: Subsequent to those developments, though, you decided to make Mr. Weiss special counsel which you had not done before.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Mr. Weiss made clear he did not ask me to be special counsel until last month. And last month I made him special counsel.

utterances.speaker: BISHOP
utterances.sentences: Did you have some lack of information that you should have had that would have caused you to act earlier to make him special counsel?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Mr. Weiss did not ask to be special counsel before.

utterances.speaker: BISHOP
utterances.sentences: I understand he didn't ask. You said that, sir. Did you take the necessary steps to inform yourself what authority he understood he had or what obstacles he was encountering?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Look, Mr. Weiss had, as I said from the beginning, at the very beginning that he had the authority over all matters that pertained to Hunter Biden.

utterances.speaker: BISHOP
utterances.sentences: Have you learned that he was, in fact, deterred by decisions of the United States Attorneys and the District of Columbia and the Northern District of California from proceeding as he thought best.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: With Respect, Congressman, Mr. Weiss has said -- has not said that he was deterred. He said that he followed the normal processes of the department, and that he was never denied the ability to bring a case in another jurisdiction.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Mr. Weiss asked for that authority, given these extraordinary circumstances of this matter and given my promise that I would give him any resources he requested. I made him special counsel.

utterances.speaker: BISHOP
utterances.sentences: So, until that time, was it just a matter of his predilection or did you undertake to investigate and discern what he was doing with his authority and what -- and whether he had faced any obstacles?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: I did not endeavor to investigate because I had promised that I would not interfere with his investigation. The way in -- to not interfere is to not investigate an investigation.

utterances.speaker: BISHOP
utterances.sentences: Once he requested to be named special counsel, having not done so over months and months of your tenure, did you ask him what had changed that made him now need to be a special counsel?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Mr. Weiss asked to be made special counsel. I had promised that I would to give him all of the resources he needed and I made him special counsel.

utterances.speaker: BISHOP
utterances.sentences: When did the Justice Department permit statutes of limitations to expire on some of the perspective charges against Hunter Biden for tax violation?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: I don't know anything about the statute of limitations here. The investigation was in the hands of Mr. Weiss to make the determines that -- determinations that he thought were appropriate.

utterances.speaker: BISHOP
utterances.sentences: Are you aware the tax -- the statute of limitations have in fact been allowed to expire after there having been tolling agreements in place?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: I'm going to say again, the determination of where to bring cases and which kinds of cases to bring was left to Mr. Weiss.

utterances.speaker: BISHOP
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir. I understand that you've said that. That's part of the problem. The question is, are you aware the statutes of limitations have been allowed to expire while the matter was under investigation?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: The investigators were fully familiar with all of the relevant law --

utterances.speaker: BISHOP
utterances.sentences: I'm not asking for the excuses. I'm asking whether you're aware of that fact, sir.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: I'm going to say again. I'm going to say again and again, if necessary. I did not interfere with. Did not investigation. Did not make determinations --

utterances.speaker: BISHOP
utterances.sentences: See, those are statements in response to other questions. Everybody in the country now knows who is paying attention to this that the Justice Department permitted statutes of limitations to expire. Every lawyer who's ever practiced understands the implications of allowing statutes of limitations to expire.

utterances.speaker: BISHOP
utterances.sentences: Prosecutors --

utterances.speaker: BISHOP
utterances.sentences: Do you not even know as you sit here whether it occurred or not?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Prosecutors make appropriate determinations on their own. In this case, I left it to Mr. Weiss whether to bring charges or not. That would include whether to let statute of limitations to expire or not. Whether there was sufficient evidence to bring a case that was subject to the statute of limitations or not. Whether there were better cases to bring or not.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The time of the gentleman has expired. The chair now recognizes the gentlelady from California.Thank you, Mr. Chairman. REP. ZOE LOFGREN (D-CA):  And thank you, Attorney General, for being here with us this morning. You know, as much as we see dirt being thrown in the air, there's a lot of misinformation that I think is intended to confuse people. I would like to ask unanimous consent to put into the record three letters from Mr. Weiss that he sent to Congress on June 7th, June 30th and July 10th.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Without objection.

utterances.speaker: LOFGREN
utterances.sentences: He said over and over again that he has full authority over this case, including the ability to seek special counsel or special attorney status if needed. You know, trying to imply otherwise is just simply false. Mr. Weiss was appointed by Then-President Trump. Your decision was to leave the Trump-appointed attorney completely in charge of this. Hands off from you. He makes all the calls without interference from the attorney general, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: That is correct.

utterances.speaker: LOFGREN
utterances.sentences: And so, the idea that you would interfere is completely wrong. And I would also like to ask -- you talked about your independence from the president, but also your independence from the Congress. Have you ever come across, historically, an instance where the Congress of the United States tried to or successfully interfered with a prosecution initiated by the Department of Justice based on the facts and the law?

utterances.speaker: LOFGREN
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: -- of Mr. North, were dismissed.

utterances.speaker: LOFGREN
utterances.sentences: Correct. Before I go into another question I have, I just would like a unanimous consent to put into the record the annual statistical transparency report dated April of 2023. It indicates that the D duplicated counting method for FBI queries of U.S. persons under the Section 702 Database numbered over 119,000. I would just like to note --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Objection.

utterances.speaker: LOFGREN
utterances.sentences: -- and we will work with you. This committee on a bipartisan basis is very concerned about querying of the 702 Database for U.S. persons without a warrant. We're not suggesting that the law does not permit that, but we are going to visit this issue because it is my view that querying the 702 Database that has been collected without due process because it relates to foreign individuals is completely wrong in terms of the privacy rights of Americans. And I just -- I'm hoping that we can work successfully with you as we craft requirements for a warrant to do that hearing (ph).I'd like to ask, you know, as we know, and has been mentioned by the ranking member, the proposal is basically to defund the police by the Republicans, to defund the FBI. I am concerned that if we defund the police as the majority has suggested, that really does have an impact on the statute of limitations. So, if we were to defund the Department of Justice, defund the FBI and the police as has been suggested. What would happen with the statute of limitations for cases that you were pursuing if you were not able to actually do that? Would they be suspended in any way or would the criminals get off scot-free?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Well, I know on my experience as a judge if I was asked a legal question and I don't know the answer, I would go back to the office and study it and I'll have to do that in this case. I don't have the answer.

utterances.speaker: LOFGREN
utterances.sentences: Well, I think I do because there's nothing in the statute that allows for the statute of limitations to be suspended because the government has been shut down or because the police have been defunded through the budget process. And I just think we ought to take the implications of a shutdown very seriously in terms of allowing criminals to get off. And I see that my time has expired, Mr. Chairman, and I yield back.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The gentlelady yields back. The chair recognizes himself."Mr. Weiss has full authority to bring cases in other jurisdictions if he feels it's necessary." That was your response, Attorney General, to Senator Grassley's question on March 1, 2023, just referencing when Mr. Bishop was questioning you. Only problem is he'd already been turned down by the U.S. attorney in the District of Columbia and Mr. Graves. So, he didn't have full authority, did he?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: I had an extended conversation with Senator Grassley at the time. We briefly touched on the Section 515 question and how that process went. I've never been suggested --

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: My point is real simple, Mr. Garland. You said he had complete authority, but he had already been turned down.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: He can't be --

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: He wanted to bring an action into the District of Columbia and the U.S. attorney there said, no, you can't. And then you go tell the United States Senate under oath that he has complete authority.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: I will say again that no one had the authority to turn him down. They could refuse to partner with him. They could not --

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: You can use whatever language refuse to partner is turning down.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Well, it's not the same under a well-known Justice Department practice.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: There's one more fact that's important and that is that this investigation was being conducted by Mr. Weiss, an appointee of President Trump. You will, at the appropriate time, have the opportunity to ask Mr. Weiss that question and he will no doubt address it in the public report that will be transmitted to the Congress. I don't know the answer to those questions.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Did they forget -- did the lawyers just, like, let it -- did they just, like, oh, darn, we let it -- did -- were they careless?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: I expect that won't be what he says, but because I promised --

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: You know that's not the case because as Mr. Bishop pointed out they had a tolling agreement. They had -- they talked to Hunter Biden's defense counsel and say, let's extend the statute of limitations. And then at some point they made an intentional decision to say, we're going to let the statute of limitations lapse. And I want to know who did that and why they did it.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Mr. Weiss was a supervisor of the investigation at that time and in all times. He made the appropriate decisions and you'll be able to ask him that question. And he will --

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: You know they did it? Everyone knows why they did it. You may not say it, but everyone knows why they did it. They -- Burisma -- those tax years -- that dealt with the -- that involved the president. It's one thing to have a gun charge in Delaware, that doesn't involve the president of the United States. But Burisma? Oh, my. That goes right to the White House. We can't have that. And we can slow walk this thing along. We can even extend the statute of limitations and then we can intentionally let it lapse. And we know this investigation was slow. Here's what everyone said, Shapley said, DOJ slow walked the investigation. Ziegler, slow walking in the approvals of everything. This happened at the Delaware attorney's office and DOJ tax level. Mr. Sobocinski, the FBI agent said, I would have liked to think -- see things move faster. Ms. Holly said the same. Every witness we've talked to said this thing was slow walked and we know why.You slow walked it long enough to let the statute of limitations run so they wouldn't have to get into Burisma. Tell me where I'm wrong.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Will the gentleman yield?

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: No, I'm asking Mr. Garland the question.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: I think I've tried to make clear that I don't know the specifics of the investigation. Much of what you are describing occurred during the Trump administration, during a Justice Department appointed by President Trump.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: No, it didn't. This is four and a half years -- this investigation. We're talking about the last few years. Your statement was just this year, March 1st to Senator Grassley.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: No, I'm sorry. I was trying to respond to your description of what the IRS agent said about certain case --

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The statute of limitations is six years, that lapsed here in the Biden administration.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: On the statute of limitations, I will say again, that the explanation for why the statute of limitation was lapsed, if it was, has to come from Mr. Weiss.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: My time is -- but let me ask one last question real quick here. Who decided that David Weiss would stay on as U.S. attorney?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Look, this occurred at -- before I came. Mr. Weiss had been kept on. I promised the --

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: No, I didn't say you can walk all through that. The White House decided.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Mr. Weiss --

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: They serve at the pleasure of the president, right?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Mr. Weiss was --

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Joe Biden decided to keep David Weiss as U.S. attorney. You weren't sworn in until March. He was -- they -- he was told he was going to stay on until February.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Chairman, your time has expired.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Pretty fundamental question. Who decided David Weiss is going to stay on as U.S. attorney general in Delaware?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Mr. Weiss was --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Chairman, your time has expired.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Mr. Chairman, your time has expired.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: I'm waiting for an answer now and I'll yield.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Well, you asked the question after your time had expired already. Point of order.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The gentleman can respond and I'll go to Ms. Jackson Lee.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Mr. Weiss was the special -- U.S. attorney for the district of Delaware when I came on. He'd been appointed by President Trump. I promised that he would be permitted to stay on for this investigation and that is what happened.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The Texas --

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: Mr. Chairman. Mr. Chairman.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The gentleman from New York is recognized.

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: Mr. Chairman, I believe you misquoted the -- from the transcript of the Senate hearing. I therefore ask you unanimous consent to enter into the record for the Senate hearing.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Without objection, but I did --

utterances.speaker: NADLER
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: OK. As I said in my opening statement, we have had an astounding number of threats against public servants over the last several years. I think that when career public servants in the Justice Department and in election workers, and airline crews, when they are singled out this can lead to threats of violence and actual violence.

utterances.speaker: JACKSON LEE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: We have the actual example of an attack on an FBI office by somebody who was incensed by political rhetoric. This does happen. We must not allow that to happen in this country.

utterances.speaker: JACKSON LEE
utterances.sentences: Does the rhetoric regarding the Biden case have any basis in reality?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, I didn't hear the first part.

utterances.speaker: JACKSON LEE
utterances.sentences: Does the rhetoric regarding the Biden case have any basis in reality?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: No, it does not.

utterances.speaker: JACKSON LEE
utterances.sentences: How does this impact FBI and DOJ employees' ability to do their work? I think you -- specifically, FBI and DOJ employees. GARLAND

utterances.speaker: JACKSON LEE
utterances.sentences: Thank you. And I assume that provisions have had to be in place to protect these agents and their families?

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry. I didn't hear the first part.

utterances.speaker: JACKSON LEE
utterances.sentences: I assume that provisions or protections have had to be in place to protect these agents and their families.

utterances.speaker: GARLAND
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's correct.
